title: How can we be sure of certainty? - Quora

response.answer_text: Short answer — If what you mean is, how one can be sure of something to be certain, I’d say you can’t always be sure of anything 100% of the time. But if what you mean is a kind of absolute certainty, then I will say you can’t, and I will argue that one should not be obsessed with being absolutely certain about anything. Long answer — Certainty, just like another kind of notion of very strong modality such as perfection, only sounds good in writings. In practical sense, being certain of anything—as much as to strive for perfection—can be a very unproductive mindset that would often lead to disappointment in oneself or in the state of affairs. In one sense, certainty is one form of perfection—it is the perfection of knowledge of something, sometimes to the point that no other possibility is allowed especially when what you’re looking at is a case for absolute certainty. cer·tain·ty — ˈsərtntē/ nounfirm conviction that something is the case. "she knew with absolute certainty that they were dead" synonyms:	confidence, sureness, positiveness, conviction, certitude, assurance "she knew with certainty that he was telling the truth" antonyms:	doubt By that standard, it certainly will be very difficult to negotiate with any sort of conviction, idea or belief that resides in the area of an absolute certainty, that we might as well forget the idea to have an honest discussion to find a mutual agreement. This kind of phenomenon occurs mainly in religious discussion, where as the position of absolute certainty will always resides on the religious, out of dogmatic belief in their teachings, often without a shadow of doubt. While being certain in moderate amount is important to make decision in life, I will argue that it should not be relied upon as the main position for the majority of our lives. It’s true that to make a decision and act upon it, some amount of certainty had to be there, else none of us would be able to be convinced to do anything. But as much goodness might come out of something, anything in moderation is better than excess of it. Cheers.
